text:
# CORONARIES: Patient with 3 vessel disease on cath. Previously found
   to be the case in [**2174**], but had been treated medically. On the floor,
   patient with recurrent chest pain and EKG changes, concerning for
   further ischemia. Chest pain has been controlled on nitro gtt. Patient
   in CCU for monitoring; plan for CABG today.
   - continue nitro gtt
   - if has further CP, would uptitrate nitro, and contact [**Name2 (NI) 9339**] and
   attending for potential balloon pump vs. urgent CABG
   - appreciate CT [**Doctor First Name 91**] recs
   - continue [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 119**], ACE-i, simvastatin

# Acute on Chronic systolic CHF: Patient with EF of 25% at OSH, but
   repeat echo at [**Hospital1 5**] showed EF of 40%, consistent with prior echo. SOB
   resolved, but still with elevated JVP (no crackles on my exam this
   morning).
   -Goal even I
s & O
s as preparation for CABG today
   -Continue BB, ACEi, [**Hospital1 119**], statin

# Social stressors: Recently lost mother to cancer, recently lost job.
   Denies SI/HI or depression.
   - social work consulted for coping

# FEN: Replete lytes PRN, NPO for CABG today
   .
   # ACCESS: PIV
   .
   # PROPHYLAXIS: IV heparin gtt
   .
   # CODE: FULL (confirmed); contact: [**Name (NI) 777**] [**Name (NI) 846**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9340**]
   .
   # DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO for CABG today.
   Glycemic Control:  Monitor blood sugars.
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2181-11-4**] 12:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: IV heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:  not intubated

# Dyspnea: Differential in this patient would be prolonged COPD
   exacebration vs. CHF. Given no fluid on CXR or exam, a hypotensive
   response to IV lasix in the ED, and a normal echocargiogram 2 weeks
   ago, a diastolic and certainly systolic heart failure exacerbation
   seems unlikely. A BNP of 150 is supportive. EKG is without acute
   changes and CK is normal. Trop of 0.02 is not conclusive for MI, but
   will be trended. Given wheezing and marked smoking history, it seems
   that this is a continued presentation of a partially treated, severe
   COPD exacerbation. Will persure treatment at this point with this
   diagnosis in mind. The physiology of his COPD is likely chronic
   bronchitis. PE r/o with CTA
   - Prednisone 60m po Qday. Will likely require a long, slow taper,
   perhaps over the course of [**3-28**] weeks.
   - Nebulaizers prn
   - PFTs as outpatient will be very important
   - hold serevent, flovent inhlaers while getting multiple short acting
   B-agonists and systemic steroids. Will continue atrovent nebs,
   -concerning that he hs such severe symptoms at such a young age.

# Lower Extremity Edema: seems consistent with chronic venous
   insufficiency. Need however, to consider right sided heart failure,
   especially given right upper quadrant pain, midl transaminitis, and
   lower exremity edema. His echo on [**2110-1-28**] showed a dialted RV cavity,
   but preserved systolic function. Other etiologies could be bialteral
   DVT, IVC DVT, or nephrotic syndrome.  His hypotensive response to
   lasix, however, may also be sine qua non of RV dysfunction and pre-load
   dependence.
   - lasix prn (hodl given recent hypotension)
   - leg elevation
   - compression stockings
# Hypertension: contineu lisinopril, extended release diltiazem

# FEN: regular, heart healthy diet
   # PPX: heparin SC, PPI as outpatient
   # DIspo; pendign clinical improvement, but does not require ICU care at
   this time. FLoor in AM
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2110-2-22**] 12:32 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

# Pneumoperitoneum - Exam reassuring.  No leukoctyosis or fevers. CT
   confirms pneumoperitoneum without free fluid, fat stranding or contrast
   leakage.
   - Continue empiric Zosyn (day 2) and metronidazole (day 2)
   - IV fluids
   - Appreciate surgery recommendations. No plan for OR currently.
   - Serial abdominal exams
   - Holding PO anti-hypertensives, substitute with IV metoprolol q6H

# Rhabdomyolysis -CK trending down from 4367 to 2738 to 1318 this AM
   -currently getting D5W 150mEq bicarb at 150cc/hour -continue to
   alkalinize urine

# Acute renal failure - [**Month (only) 60**] be pre-renal or secondary to
   rhabdomyolysis. Creatinine down from 1.7 to 1.3.
   - Continue aggressive IV fluid hydration
   - Monitor potassium (3.8 this AM)
   - Renally dose antibiotics

# Pulmonary embolism - Recheck coagulation factors.
   -Current INR 1.4.  Consider restarting heparin gtt and starting
   Warfarin with goal INR [**3-11**].
   - Need to clarify dosing with PCP for [**Name9 (PRE) 4168**] restarting
# Diabetes - Insulin 70/30 at 1/2 of home dose, and sliding scale

# Lower extremity ulcers - Wound care consult
   - vascular surgery has assessed and recommended ace wrap, leg
   elevation, and wet to dry dressings if open blisters
   - wound/skin nurse consulted

# FEN:  NPO, IV fluids, replete electrolytes, alkalinize urine
   .
   # Access: peripheral IV x2, foley catheter, rectal tube
   .
   # PPx:  Pantoprazole.  SubQ heparin.
   .
   # Code:  Full code
   .
   # Dispo:  ICU until above resolved.
   .
   # Comm:
   [**Name (NI) 237**] (neighbor and healthcare proxy)
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2198-9-17**] 12:01 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2198-9-17**] 02:21 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

# Hypotension:  Given patient's acute kidney injury (with FeUrea of
   26%), complaint of thirst, low urine output, and physical exam
   consistent with dehydration, his hypotension could be solely attributed
   to hypovolemia.  In setting of fever to 103 in ED, leukocystosis to
   12.6, and recent admissions for sepsis, this seems the most likely
   cause of his hypotension.   We are currently targeting therapy to prior
   ESBL organism with vanc and meropenem.  C diff is another possible
   source, as patient with recent antibiotic course for PNA and several
   episodes loose stools.  There is also the concern for a cardiogenic
   component of hypotension, but with preserved central venous O2 sat this
   would seem to be less likely.  With his hypotension we will have to
   continue to titrate down pressors and maintain an effective cardiac
   output.
   - Norepinephrine to keep MAPs > 65
   - Gently hydrate with 500 mL boluses given EF of 15% and history of
   volume overload, as well as DNR/DNI status
   - continue empiric vancomycin and meropenem pending culture results
   - Follow-up blood, urine cultures, stool and sputum Cx
   - f/u c diff
   - restart home dose digoxin with the hope of improving cardiac output

# Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Patient was not initially complaining of dyspnea while at home. Upon
   transit to the ED was noted to have a low oxygen sat in the 70s and was
   placed on NRB and subsequently was placed on BiPAP in the ED. While in
   the emergency department, oxygen sats recovered and supplemental oxygen
   was titrated down. On the floor was maintaining oxygen sat of 100% on
   RA; however, initial ABG showed a pO2 of 56. 100% facemask was applied
   and sat increased appropriately to 441. A-a gradient difficult to
   calculate given unknown exact oxygen percent delivery with face mask.
   - Maintain patient on supplemental 3L NC and titrate down as tolerated
   - continue prn albuterol nebs
   - TTE with bubble study to rule-out intracardiac shunt as cause of his
   odd ABG findings of low pO2 despite observed normal sat
   - Consider CT chest in future to rule-out possibility of organizing
   pneumonia causing A-a gradient

# Altered Mental Status: Improved overnight with MAP > 65 following
   several fluid boluses and increased pressors.  Most likely related to
   decreased perfusion of the brain, although ICU delirium is also a
   possibility given that pt has been in and out of ICU for past several
   months. Will continue to monitor.  NCHCT negative.
   - Continue rehydration and with prn fluid boluses to maintain UOP > 30
   cc/hr and MAP > 65.

# Fever: Patient noted to be febrile to 103 rectally in the ED.
   Possible that this is component of sepsis with unknown primary source
   vs influenza. No fevers since that time.
   - Empiric vancomycin and meropenem (need to readjust meds as renal
   function worsens or improves)
   - Nasopharyngeal swab for influenza DFA neg and tamiflu stopped

# Acute kidney injury:
   Recent baseline Cr 1.1 - 1.3 upon discharge on [**2170-11-27**]. At
   presentation to the ED was Cr 2.5. Urine lytes performed in ED revealed
   a FeUrea of 26%.  Cr improved to 1.7 today.
   - Continue to trend BUN/Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   - Hold furosemide unless patient becomes acutely dyspneic

# Hyponatremia:
   Improved to 128 from 123 at discharge on [**2170-11-27**]. 132 this AM. Will
   monitor with rehydration.
   - Trend sodium

# COPD:
   [**Last Name (un) **] recent PFTs or overall disease status. Reported to be on home
   supplemental oxygen, though unknown when this was started.
   - Investigate indications for home oxygen and history of COPD
   - Continue home albuterol, tiotropium, fluticasone/salmeterol

# Anemia with baseline Hct 24, current Hct 28.7:
   Likely elevated from baseline because of hemoconcentration.
   - Maintain active type and screen
   - Trend with rehydration

# Adrenal insufficiency:
   Patient on 10 mg hydrocortisone at home.
   - Increase to 50 mg hydrocortisone given stress of acute illness (day 2
   today)

# h/o PE, on coumadin: Remote chance that a transient PE could explain
   current presentation of hypoxia and hypotension.
   -continue coumadin with goal INR [**1-30**]

# Atrial fibrillation:
   Stable v-paced rhythm on telemetry at this time. Digoxin 0.5 on
   admission labs.
   - Restart digoxin today as above
   - Hold metoprolol while hypotensive

# Hypertension:
   - Hold home antihypertensives

# Hyperlipidemia:
   - Hold atorvastatin

ICU Care
   Nutrition: Regular diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2170-11-29**] 09:30 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2170-11-29**] 09:30 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2170-11-29**] 12:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: coumadin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

# Tachyarrhythmia: The patient has a h/o afib on coumadin although
   rhythm currently appears regular likely aflutter She was given 5 mg IV
   lopressor x 2 and 25 mg po, but her HR remained in the 130's.  She was
   started on an amiodarone gtt and po amiodarone and an A-line was
   placed.  She continued to be tachycardic and was then given 150 mg IV
   bolus of amiodarone.  She was also started on neo as her SBP dropped
   when the amiodarone was started.  In the am she was still tachy to the
   130's so she was given another 150 mg IV bolus of amiodarone.
   - Continue amiodarone loading and 200 mg of po amiodarone [**Hospital1 **].  Also
   continue metoprolol 12.5 mg [**Hospital1 **].

# Respiratory distress/COPD/PNA: The patient has a history of COPD,
   likely exacerbated by by her tachyarrhythmia and fluid overload. On
   High-flow over the day and last night.  ABG on arrival was 7.45/39/55
   and there was discussion about intubating her, however she was strongly
   against being intubated, even after it was explained that it would only
   be for a short amount of time.  Her family discussed the issue with
   her, but by the time she had agreed to undergo intubation, she had
   improved somewhat so she was continued on the high flow mask.  She was
   given 80 mg IV lasix x 1 for diuresis in the afternoon and over night
   started on a low-dose lasix gtt for continued diuresis as her CXR
   showed evdience of pulmonary edema.  There was also a question of an
   aspiration PNA at the OSH.
   - Continue ventilatory support with high-flow oxygen.  If the patient
   clinically decomensates, would need to intubate her.
   - Continue gentle diuresis with the lasix given her vol overload on CXR
   (likely [**2-16**] transfusion, IVF at OSH), goal I/O 500 cc to 1 L neg over
   next 24hrs.
   - COPD treatment including advair, spiriva, and standing atrovent nebs
   and xopenex nebs
   - Continue levo/flagyl for a possible aspiration PNA until her
   respiratory status is stable.  Will send a sputum culture.

# NSTEMI: Likely secondary to demand from anemia, resp distress, and
   tachycardia. CK 159 -->139 --> 115
98  MB 12 --> 9 --> 7
5  Trop 0.39
   --> 0.38 --> 0.37
 0.23.  Currently chest pain free.
   - As her CEs have been trending down, no need to continue trending.
   - once her HR is better controlled, consider checking a TTE
   - Continue 12.5 mg of metoprolol [**Hospital1 **] and her statin.
   - no ASA, no heparin [**2-16**] GI bleeding

# GIB: GI aware but patient not stable currently for endoscopy; given
   concurrent NSTEMI, risk:benefit ratio may favor endoscopy earlier, as
   definitively addressing bleeding may allow earlier
   anticoagulation/antiplatelet therapy.  INR reversed at OSH, this am
   1.3.  No further clinical evidence of bleeding.
   - Continue hold anticoagulation for now
   - continue Protonix IV.
   - Appreciate GI consult, will f/u recs
   - Hct has been in the low 30
s and stable.  Can check another Hct in 8
   hrs and if stable, move to [**Hospital1 **] Hct checks.

# h/o CVA: on anticoagulation as outpatient but GIB currently precludes
   this
   - monitor neuro exam
   - hold anticoagulation due to recent GIB

hypertension: Her BP was elevated on admission likely from
   respiratory distress.  She was given metoprolol for rate control and
   loaded with amiodarone as above and her SBPs dropped to the point she
   required neo for a short period of time.
   -  Continue to monitor BP closely.
# Hypercholesterolemia: Continue statin
# Depression: Continue citalopram

Code: FULL
   # Contact: daughter [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 3600**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 3601**] (h), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 3602**] (w);
   also spoke with son [**Name (NI) 1247**] at bedside
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2178-2-6**] 04:04 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2178-2-6**] 07:19 PM

   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

Dyspnea:  Likely multifactorial secondary to large right sided
   pulmonary embolism, large right sided pleural effusion, right lung
   collapse.  All findings not present on previous CT scan from late
   [**Month (only) **] when she was diagnosed.  No signs and symptoms of infection
   presently.  Lymphangitic spread of tumor may also be contributing to
   her symptoms. Given the acuity of her presentation suspect a large
   component is related to acute infarction. No indications for lysis at
   this time given that she is hemodynamically stable and BNP and
   troponins are within normal limits.
   - continue heparin
   - wean oxygen as tolerated
   -pleural fluid mostly blood, likely malignant. Will follow up cytology.

Anemia: Patient has had a significant drop in her HCT today. Will check
   repeat CXR to ensure that she is not bleeding into her pleural fluid,
   guaiac stool. If CXR worsening will get CT to assess for blood in
   pleural fluid.
   -Guaiac stool
   -CXR
   -HCT 1pm
   -Will inform IP of drop in setting of recent thoracentesis

Non-small cell lung cancer:  Patient was scheduled to initiate
   chemotherapy shortly.  Now presents with dyspnea, large effusion and
   pulmonary embolism.
   - oncology recs:
   ----Lovenox 1mg/kg q12
   ----transfer to OMED when more stable
Hypokalemia: Replete with oral K sliding scale

Anxiety:
   -Receiving Xanax PRN anxiety

Hypertension:
   - holding all antihypertensive [**Doctor Last Name 23**]

Diabetes:
   - insulin sliding scale

Hyperlipidemia:
   - continue simvastatin

FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, cardiac, diabetic diet
   Prophylaxis: heparin
   Access: peripherals
   Code:  Full
   Communication: Patient, Husband [**Name (NI) 366**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9246**]
   [**Name2 (NI) 1531**]osition: OMED floor
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2171-12-25**] 02:03 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2171-12-25**] 02:04 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

Hypotension/tachycardia/hypothermia: Patient hypotensive,
   tachycardic, hypothermic, concerning for signs of active infection.
   Currently calling this SIRS and possible seppsis.  Source likely to be
   pulmonary, although cannot exclude GI (SBP possible given peritoneal
   fluid results), GU (UA negative in ED), skin (patient's rash unlikely
   cellulitis), c diff.  Other potential etiologies would be
   endocrinopathy (adrenal insuficiency, thyroid disorder), or possible
   central etiology such as lesion to hypothalamus.  Infection is
   currently the leading differential and needs to be treated broadly.
   - Continue vancomycin, zosyn
   - Consult infectious disease regarding other antibiotic choices to use
   - If clinically does not improve, consider consulting IP regarding
   tapping right pleural effusion
   - Continue to obtain daily blood cultures
   - Follow up cultures
   - Monitor fever curve
   - Attempt to place arterial line
   - Follow up final CT abdomen read
   - Early goal directed treatment: CVP 8-12, MAP > 65, ScvO2 > 70.
   - Continue bear hugger.
   .

SBP. Likely given peritoneal fluid results. Questionable whether
   would present in the manner that it has in this patient; likely to be
   another source of infection.
   - Continue vancomycin, zosyn
   - Consult infectious disease regarding other antibiotic choices to use
   - Follow up cultures
   .

Right pleural effusion. Cannot rule out right lower quadrant
   pneumonia, likely nosocomial (MRSA/pseudomonal). Likely etiology for
   patient's shortness of breath, productive cough. Also consider CHF,
   aspiration;
   - Obtain repeat CXR AM
   - Follow up final CXR read
   - If clinically does not improve, consider consulting IP regarding
   tapping right pleural effusion
   - Start nebulizer treatment
   .

Tachycardia: Patient with a history of A-Fib.  Does not seem to be on
   anything for rate control at baseline.  Currently tachycardia is likely
   [**12-29**] SIRS/Sepsis physiology and compensatory increase in cardiac
   output.  Other potential causes are from the pressors and simply A-Fib
   with RVR.  Currently tachy to 120s.  Potentially could slow down to
   attempt to improve BP, however seems a little counterintuitive given
   already low BP and likely hypotension is not only from tachycardia.
   - Continue to monitor
   .
